English phonetics, which would enable Weary to ask Germans questions such as ‘Where is your headquarters?’ and ‘How many howitzers have you?’ Or to tell them, ‘Surrender. Your situation is hopeless,’ and so on.

This showcases a ridiculous idea that Americans were to immediately start questioning the Germans about the information they were in no way going to give up. It also shows the focus on terms that have to do with tactics and war rather than practical questions. By far the most important thing this sentence shows is the characterization of Billy as the ever faithful soldier. He held onto all these unnecessary things because he was told to do so. It also shows his lack of experience of war in a way. He didn’t understand that all these items might slow him down.
‘You guys go on without me,’ he said again and again

Vonnegut is portraying Billy in a childish way in this sentence. A small child would whine in the same way “are we there yet” on a road trip. While we are already enlightened that Billy is a “greenhorn” in war, this comment  makes him seem even more green. After all the mantra of soldiers is perseverance, and fighting spirit. Billy is portrayed in an opposite light.
The Americans had no choice but to leave trails in the show as unambiguous as diagrams in a book on ballroom dancing--step, slide, rest-step, slide, rest.
This meaning that they were trying to hide their footprints by making them look un-recognizable or un-readable, such as a diagram that says how to ballroom dance.
So it goes.
The constant repetition of this line in the midst of death or tragedy reveals the numbness underneath the narrator´s voice. It helps the reader infer the devastation the character has been through.
Like so many Americans, she was trying to construct a life that made sense from things she found in gift shops.

Another reference to American consumerism.

Vonnegut is referring to two things in his typical acerbic way.  For one thing, Americans often think that “things” will buy them happiness, and frequently these “things” are useless pretty junk.

But more importantly, Vonnegut is criticising the platitudes found on gift shop trinkets, philosophically dumbed down phrases that have little or nothing to do with thinking. It is noted, that a cross (symbolising one’s faith and devotion to God) is simply bought and sold in tacky giftshops.
Frames are where the money is.
A reference to the uniquely American spirit of consumerism. The line’s tone indicates that this focus on the bottom line is a product of Billy’s upbringing in American society.
Basement rumpus room

“Rumpus room” is synonymous with Recreation room, or Rec room for short.

This addition to the home reveals a degree of upper-middle class luxury and indicates Billy’s economic status.
Ilium, New York

Vonnegut’s work Cat’s Cradle also takes place, in part, in Ilium, New York, a fictional town.

Vonnegut may have derived the name from the upstate town of Troy. Indeed, Ilium is the Latin word for the ancient city of Troy.

Again, by re-using characters from previous novels and setting his stories in the same areas, Vonnegut constructs his own universe, one that avid fans find familiar and even comfortable.

He spoke unintelligibly of the sacrifices he had made on Billy’s behalf. He dilated upon the piety and heroism of ‘The Three Musketeers,’ portrayed, in the most glowing and impassioned hues, their virtue and magnanimity, the imperishable honor they acquired for themselves, and the great services they rendered to Christianity.

Vonnegut’s use of high-level diction to describe the “unintelligible” rantings of Roland Weary separates the reader from the latter’s emotions. Vonnegut’s eloquence in the face of Weary’s blinding rage parallels the emotional control that Billy Pilgrim always displays. If Vonnegut would have chosen to have Weary soliloquize on his anger, the passage would have a much different effect.
There wasn’t anybody else there, or any thing. There was just violet light and a hum.

The color violet correlates to the third eye Chakra, the Chakra associated with extraordinary perceptions. Each of the 7 chakras also has a sound vibration. Vonnegut’s ties to late 1960s counterculture may have given him insight into this aspect of eastern philosophy. Billy’s perception of death, in that case, is total connection to the third eye chakra.
